questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Odland Bodies are present in Stratum Basale

 

Option C: Odland Bodies (Lamellar Bodies or Keratinosomes /Membrane Coating Granules):

 

  • Located in upper stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum (NOT Stratum basale)
  • Discharge lipid components for barrier function and intercellular cohesion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stratum Corneum: (Horny layer)

 

  • Composed of non-nucleated cells that don't divide.
  • Barrier function: It stops fluids from the body from leaking into the environment and stops environmental microbes from entering the body.
  • Changes during keratinocyte ascent:
  1. Loss of nucleus,
  2. Size increase,
  3. Shape flattening,
  4. Dehydration,
  5. Loss of metabolic activity.

 

Option B: Stratum Lucidum (Clear Cell Layer): (sandwiched between the granulosum and corneum)

 

  • Found in thick skin of palms and soles.
  • Contains eleidin granules, giving it the translucent appearance.
  • Abundance of keratin filaments and eleidin granules.
  • These cells could be considered transition cells because they are still nucleated.

 

Option D:

 

  • Below the papillary dermis is the skin's superficial vascular plexus.
  • The vascular supply in the dermis is abundant (unlike the epidermis which is avascular). The Dermis can be separated into papillary dermis (upper 1/10) & Reticular Dermis (lower 9/10)
  • The Deep Vascular Plexus is present below the reticular dermis, and the superficial vascular plexus is present between the papillary and reticular dermis (Subpapillary Plexus).

 

  • Reactive units of skin. The Superficial Reactive Unit (SRU) comprises the Epidermis (E), the Junction zone (J), and the papillary body (PB, or papillary dermis) with the superficial microvascular plexus. The Dermal Reactive Unit (DRU) consists of the Reticular Dermis (RD) and the Deep Dermal Microvascular Plexus (DVP). The subcutaneous reactive unit (S) consists of lobules (L) and septae (Sep). A fourth unit is the appendages (A; hair and sebaceous glands are the only appendages shown). HF, hair follicle.

 

Superficial Vascular Plexus:

 

  • Provides nutrients, oxygen, and temperature control.
  • Superficial plexus controls blood flow for heat regulation.

 

The location of the papillary and reticular layers of the dermis are depicted in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the characteristics and contents of each layer of the epidermis, and recognize the location of various structures within the skin layers, such as the Odland bodies and the superficial vascular plexus.

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acantholysis is seen in Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Option B: Bullous pemphigoid which is a subepidermal blistering  disorder, does NOT exhibit acantholysis.

 

  • Acantholysis is the breakdown of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, which causes keratinocytes to become less cohesive.
  • Acantholytic cells/Tzanck cells are Circular, Prominent Nucleus with Peri-nuclear Halo

            ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    

 

 

Acantholysis is classified as -

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Actinic keratosis and psoriasis frequently exhibit parakeratosis, which is suggested by nucleated stratum corneum.

 

  • The term "parakeratosis" describes an abnormal keratinization process in which basal layer cells divide quickly, reaching the stratum corneum faster and failing to shed their nuclei.
  • As a result, the nucleated stratum corneum is observed on histopathology.

 

Parakeratosis (nucleated stratum corneum) can be seen in the below image pointed by black arrows.

 

 

Option C: Spongiosis is the characteristic histopathological feature of acute eczema

Intercellular edema involving the stratum spinosum is characteristic of spongiosis.

 

 

Option D: Acanthosis is characterised by an increase in the number of stratum spinosum cells, leading to its increased thickness. Other histological changes like Hypergranulosis, Hyperkeratosis, and Papillomatosis are frequently present in patients with acanthosis. It appears in Lupus Vulgaris, Verruca Vulgaris, and Chronic Eczema.

 

Below is an illustration of acanthosis. Notice the increased thickness of the Malpighian layer & elongated rete ridges.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis is a feature of Pemphigus Vulgaris, not Bullous Pemphigoid, while parakeratosis is a hallmark of psoriasis, spongiosis is characteristic of acute eczema, and acanthosis indicates the thickening of the stratum spinosum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with flaccid bullae on his trunk and oral mucosa. The blisters rupture easily upon minor trauma. A skin biopsy is taken and shows intraepidermal blisters with loss of connections between epidermal cells. What is the primary structure affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intercellular Substance

 

Option D: Intercellular Substance:

 

  • Acantholysis is due to the destruction or loss of cohesion of the intercellular substance, causing the epidermal cells to separate from one another.
  • This leads to the formation of intraepidermal blisters, as seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epidermis:

 

  • While acantholysis manifests in the epidermis, the entire layer isn’t destroyed.
  • Instead, acantholysis is characterized by a loss of cohesion between individual epidermal cells, specifically within the intercellular substance.

 

Option B. Dermis:

 

  • The dermis is the layer beneath the epidermis and provides support to the epidermis.
  • Acantholysis is primarily an epidermal process, and the dermis remains unaffected.

 

Option C. Basement membrane:

 

  • The basement membrane acts as a barrier between the epidermis and dermis, supporting the epidermal cells and anchoring them to the dermis.
  • In acantholysis, the basement membrane remains intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis is primarily due to the loss of cohesion within the intercellular substance of the epidermis, leading to intraepidermal blistering.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 918

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with concerns about patchy skin pigmentation, which has become more pronounced after her recent beach vacation. A biopsy of the affected skin is likely to show increased activity in which layer of the epidermis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stratum Basale

 

Option B: Melanocytes are found in the stratum basale, the deepest layer of the epidermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • They produce melanin, which gives skin its color and protects against UV radiation.
  • The increased pigmentation observed in the patient is due to the activity of melanocytes in this layer.

 

Option A. Stratum Spinosum:

 

  • This layer is known for its spiny appearance due to desmosomal connections between keratinocytes.
  • While melanin can be transferred to keratinocytes here, melanocytes themselves are not located in this layer.

 

Option C. Stratum Corneum:

 

  • This is the outermost layer of the skin, composed of dead keratinocytes that have migrated from lower layers.
  • It does not contain melanocytes.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum:

 

  • This layer contains keratinocytes that are in the process of keratinization, preparing to move up to the stratum corneum.
  • It does not house melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanocytes, the cells responsible for pigment production, are in the Stratum Basale of the epidermis.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 7

questions.text:
A 52-year-old patient presents with flaccid blisters on the trunk and proximal extremities. Skin biopsy shows intraepidermal blistering with acantholytic cells. Direct immunofluorescence of the skin reveals intercellular IgG deposits within the epidermis. Below is the Assertion and Reason related to this case scenario, mark the option which correctly describes the underlying pathology of this condition?

 

Assertion: Desmosomes are damaged in pemphigus.

 

Reason: Pemphigus has autoimmunity against desmoglein.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and reason are true & reason is the correct explanation of assertion

 

Option A. Pemphigus is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against Desmoglein, which is a key component of desmosomes, leading to their disruption and consequent intraepidermal blistering. This option is correct.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The assertion is correct, but in this case, the reason is directly related to the assertion and is the correct explanation.

 

Option C. Both the assertion and the reason are true, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Both the assertion and the reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The learner should recognize that in pemphigus, autoantibodies target Desmoglein, a constituent of desmosomes, leading to their damage and resulting in the clinical manifestation of intraepidermal blisters.

 

Ref:  Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 915

questions.text: Diascopy can be used for clinical examination of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: All of the above - Diascopy can be utilized to evaluate all these conditions. It helps in differentiating vascular lesions, which blanch when pressure is applied, from hemorrhagic ones, which do not.

 

Diascopy/Vitropression: It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colourless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colours to be evaluated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Purpura - Diascopy is used to determine whether red or purple skin lesions are blanchable. Purpuric lesions do not blanch when pressure is applied, helping to distinguish them from lesions that are due to vasodilation.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris - This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. A positive diascopy test in lupus vulgaris shows apple jelly nodules, which are a characteristic finding.

 

Option C. Nevus Anemicus - This is a congenital condition characterized by localized areas of skin that do not have normal vasomotor responses. Diascopy can demonstrate that the lesions blanch with pressure and match the surrounding skin because they do not contain more blood vessels, but rather less responsive ones.

 

 

Blanching response with Diascopy can be seen in below image:

 

 

 

(a) Brown-reddish infiltrated scaly plaques on the auricle and periauricular area,

(b) Diascopic examination showing the presence of light-brownish or “apple jelly” coloured nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diascopy is a clinical test used to evaluate blanching of skin lesions and can be applied to a variety of conditions including purpura, lupusvulgaris, and nevusanemicus to assess the nature of skin discoloration.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady diagnosed with Skin malignancy & she underwent chemotherapy, presents with hair loss after 3 weeks of starting of chemotherapy. Identify the INCORRECT statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair does not regrow once the Offending Agent is Stopped.

 

Option C.

  • It is incorrect. Typically, hair regrows after the cessation of chemotherapy, although it may have a different texture or color.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This condition is known as Anagen effluvium. Correct:

  • It is hair loss that occurs during the anagen or growth phase of the hair cycle, commonly induced by chemotherapy.
  • Hair regrows once offending chemotherapy agent is stopped.
  • It is due to the anagen, or proliferating phase of the hair cycle being adversely affected.
  • Following the start of chemotherapy, hair loss usually starts within 1-3 weeks and is finished within 1-2 months.

 

Option B. It is an example for Diffuse Hair Loss. Correct:

  • It is indeed an example of Diffuse hair loss, where hair loss occurs uniformly across the scalp, often because of systemic treatment like chemotherapy.

 

Option D. Hair loss finished within 1-2 months of chemotherapy. Correct:

  • It typically occurs rapidly after the start of chemotherapy and can continue for a short period after the therapy has concluded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss, or Anagen effluvium, is a type of Diffuse hair loss that generally resolves after the completion of chemotherapy, with hair regrowth occurring over time.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.7, 89.48

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with heavy hair loss for 4 months. She gives a history of suffering with COVID 19, 8 months back. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Telogen Effluvium

 

Option A.

  • Telogen effluvium:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Androgenetic Alopecia. Incorrect:

  • It is characterized by a patterned hair loss and is a genetic condition.
  • It's less likely to be associated with a recent illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia Areata. Incorrect:

  • It usually presents with patchy hair loss and is an autoimmune disorder.
  • The hair loss is not typically diffuse as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania. Incorrect:

  • It is a hair-pulling disorder, which typically results in irregular areas of broken hairs of varying length, usually not consistent with a history of illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Telogen effluvium is a likely diagnosis in patients presenting with diffuse hair loss following a significant stressor such as illness, in this case, COVID-19.
  • This condition usually resolves spontaneously as the effects of the stressor diminish.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous remission is seen in 10% of the patients, in case of limited alopecia areata.

 

Option C.

  • From the clinical & histological clues given in this question, this patient has alopecia areata.
  • Spontaneous remission is seen in 80% of the patients, in case of limited Alopecia areata. (NOT 10% as mentioned in Option C)
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Auto-immune disease that causes non-scarring patchy hair loss.
     
  • It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals.
     
  • It is Associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Exclamation Mark Hair

  • This refers to short extractable broken hairs which are thinner towards the base as shown in the image below
     

 

Option B. Alopecia Totalis:

  • It means loss of all scalp hair & alopecia universalis means loss of all body hair.

 

Option D. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata:

  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease.
  • If it advances quickly, sparing white hair, this leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called Turning white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia areata is characterized by patchy hair loss, exclamation mark hair, and potential for complete scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis), and while spontaneous remission is common, it occurs in 80% of cases with limited disease.

questions.text: A 19-Year-Old Girl came to Dermatology OPD with complaints of Facial Lesions. On examination, Multiple Comedones, Papules, Pustules & Nodulocystic Lesions were present. Most likely Diagnosis for these examination findings in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acne Vulgaris

 

Option B.

 

  • The age of the patient & the presence of comedones, papules , pustules & nodulocystic lesions on the face are suggestive of acne vulgaris.

 

 

  • It is commonly seen in Teenagers & Young Adults.
  • The condition can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring due to sinus formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acne Rosacea or Rosacea:

 

  • It is predominantly a disease with onset in middle aged adults (30-50 years old) & involves the convexities of the face.
  • Comedones are absent in Rosacea

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

  • The lesions of lichen planus can be described as 5Ps – Purple Polygonal, Pruritic, Plane Topped (Flat), Papules. NOT as described in this question.

 

Option D. Scabies:

 

  • Adult Scabies does not have Facial lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acne vulgaris is diagnosed by the presence of comedones, inflammatory papules, pustules, and occasionally nodules, primarily on the face, chest, and back, and is a common dermatological condition among teenagers and young adults.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.21 & 90.22

questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Isotretinoin

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oral Steroids:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who has had Erythematous Papulo Pustular Lesions over the Centre of her Face for the past two years comes to the Dermatology OPD. Comedones are absent. Background Erythema and Telangiectasia are present. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rosacea

 

Option B.

 

  • The patient presents with erythema and papules on the central face, which are symptoms of acne rosacea.
  • Alcohol, spicy food, sunlight exposure, and emotional disturbances can all cause it.
  • Later on, telangiectasia also appears in patients.
  • Additionally, they frequently experience rapid flushing in response to temperature changes.
  • Rosacea is more common in women between the ages of 30 and 50.
  • In rosacea, the innate immune response seems to be altered. There is increased protease activity as well as increased toll-like receptor 2 TLR-2 activity.
  • Proliferation of Demodex mites in the pilosebaceous follicles of the face has also been proposed as a potential aetiological factor in cutaneous & ocular inflammation.
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction appears to be closely linked to the pathogenesis of ocular rosacea.

Option A. Acne

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

Option D. Melasma

 

  • This presents as symmetrical hyperpigmented patches on the face, without papulopustular lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rosacea should be considered in adults presenting with Central Facial Erythema, Papulopustular Lesions, and Telangiectasia, particularly in the Absence of Comedones.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with the following skin finding. Which of the following clinical signs will aid in Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz Sign

 

Option B.

 

  • One defining characteristic of psoriasis is the presence of silvery white scaly plaques on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knees.
  • Its diagnosis is aided by the grattage test.
  • The act of scratching (grattage) psoriasis scales causes air keratin interfaces to form, giving the scales a more silvery appearance.
  • When all the scales are removed, the basement membrane becomes visible and appears as a moist, red surface (the Bulkley membrane), through which dilated capillaries at the tips of elongated dermal papillae are torn, creating numerous bleeding points.
  • The Auspitz sign is the name for the traditional pin-point bleeding.

 

 

Underlying Cause:

 

  • The Auspitz sign is caused by suprapapillary epidermal thinning and elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papillae.

 

However, the Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin Biopsy:

 

  • It is a diagnostic procedure that can help to differentiate between various skin conditions by providing histopathological evidence.
  • However, it is not a clinical sign but rather a diagnostic tool and may not be necessary for classic presentations of psoriasis.

 

Option C. KOH Smear:

 

  • It is used to diagnose fungal infections by revealing fungal elements in the skin flakes when examined under a microscope.
  • This would not aid in diagnosing psoriasis, which is not a fungal infection.

 

Option D. Besnier’s Sign/Scratch Sign/Stroke of the Nail/Coup d’ongle Sign:

 

  • The fine branny scales of pityriasis versicolor may become visible after scratching the lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Auspitz sign is a clinical indicator of psoriasis, characterized by pinpoint bleeding when scales from a psoriatic plaque are scraped away.
  • This sign can be useful in the clinical diagnosis of psoriasis without the need for invasive testing.

  • This refers to clusters of neutrophils within the epidermis.

questions.text: In Which of the following cases would you prescribe systemic corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 26-year-old Woman with Impetigo Herpetiformis

 

Option A.

 

  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare form of pustular psoriasis occurring during pregnancy.
  • It can be severe and is potentially life-threatening for both the mother and fetus, often requiring systemic corticosteroids as part of the management.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis / pregnancy-related pustular psoriasis, & Erythrodermic Psoriasis in pregnancy are definitive reasons to prescribe systemic steroids in psoriasis.
  • Additionally, steroids may be used to treat acute psoriasis pustular symptoms like ARDS.
  • Tar & dithranol are absolutely contraindicated in pustular psoriasis.
  • The only clear-cut indication for systemic steroids is pregnancy, as they are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis due to the risk of sudden withdrawal causing severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis:

 

  • While systemic corticosteroids might be used in severe psoriatic arthritis, they are generally not the first-line treatment due to potential long-term side effects and the availability of other treatments like DMARDs (Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs) or biologics.

 

Option C. Guttate Psoriasis:

 

  • Guttate psoriasis often resolves on its own and is usually treated with topical therapies or light therapy rather than systemic corticosteroids, unless other treatments have failed, and the condition is severe.
  • DOC - Erythromycin (Macrolides)

 

Option D. Erythrodermic Psoriasis

 

  • Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe form of psoriasis that can be life-threatening and may require systemic treatment (Methotrexate); however, systemic corticosteroids are used with caution due to the risk of causing a rebound flare upon withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prescribe systemic corticosteroids for a 26-year-old woman with Impetigo herpetiformis, which is a pustular psoriasis of pregnancy requiring aggressive management due to its potential severity.

questions.text: Identify the Type of Psoriasis in the given picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guttate

 

Option A.

 

The picture shows a classical picture of Guttate Psoriasis.

 

  • Following a pharyngitis attack, the clinical stem of small red drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (illustrated in the image) is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis.
  • HLA C 06:02 is associated with it.
  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate manifests as a sudden onset shower of small lesions that are more prominent on the trunk and proximal limbs. Following infection with group A Streptococcus, it is more prevalent in children and young adults and frequently the first sign of psoriasis. It can also happen in adults who have plaque psoriasis that first manifested in childhood.
  • Usually, lesions disappear after three months. Future plaque psoriasis development is a possibility in some patients with acute guttate psoriasis.

 

Guttate psoriasis Treatment:

 

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials - recurrent episodes may be linked to the patient's or a close relative's pharyngeal carriage of the culpable streptococcus. To eliminate chronic streptococcal carriage, a course of semi-synthetic penicillin and rifampin may be necessary.
  • In phototherapy, broadband UVB has a better response than NBUVB.

 

Note:

 

  • Plaque and follicular psoriasis both have a chronic course.
  • Patients with pustular psoriasis may experience cachexia, hypocalcemia, erythroderma, and fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erythrodermic Psoriasis:

 

  • This is a severe form of psoriasis where the skin appears extensively red and inflamed.
  • The skin sheds in sheets rather than scales.
  • It lacks the distinct drop-shaped papules of guttate psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pustular Psoriasis:

 

  • Characterized by white blisters of non-infectious pus surrounded by red skin.
  • The main feature is the presence of pustules, which are not described in your picture.

 

Option D. Inverse Psoriasis:

 

  • Found in the folds of the skin, such as under the armpits, in the groin, under the breasts, and other areas.
  • Appears as very red, smooth, and shiny lesions.
  • Unlike other forms, it lacks the classic scales seen in the "Rain Drop" pattern of guttate psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Guttate Psoriasis by its classic presentation of numerous small, drop-like papules, often appearing after a streptococcal infection, which is distinct from other psoriasis types that have different presentations and localizations.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of extremely itchy lesions over his hands. On examination following cutaneous lesions are present over the body. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen Planus

 

Option A.

 

  • The skin lesion in the preceding image features the distinctive purple, flat, polygonal papules of lichen planus.
  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • It commonly affects the wrists, forearms, and genitalia.

 

 

  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia
  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop.
  • It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • It typically presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most often on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees, and may involve the scalp and nails.

 

Option C. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

  • It usually shows orange-red plaques with a characteristic "islands of sparing," and keratotic follicular papules, which are not as pruritic as lichen planus.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rosea

 

  • It often begins with a single "herald patch," followed by a "Christmas tree" distribution of smaller lesions on the trunk, which are not typically as itchy as lichen planus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with pruritic, purple, polygonal papules, consider Lichen Planus as the most likely diagnosis, and differentiate it from other dermatoses like psoriasis, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and pityriasis rosea based on lesion morphology and distribution.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 37 Page No 37.1

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the Derma OPD with thickened palms & Soles. These lesions were insidious in onset. He was diagnosed with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris. Which of the following features is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Islands of Sparing Over Body

 

Option C.

 

Features of PRP:

 

  • Dry scaly plaques with salmon red or orange red colour are characteristically seen; these plaques coalesce to leave islands of normal skin, commonly referred to as islands of sparing, between the lesions.
  • Trunk: the most typical location.
  • The image below shows islands of sparing in pityriasis rubra pilaris.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis causes nutmeg grater papules to appear on the elbow and wrist.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma causes keratoderma on the sole to be so thick that it resembles a sandal.

 

 

  • Thickened, discoloured nails that are distally showing splinter haemorrhages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nail pitting

 

  • It is commonly seen in psoriasis, not typically in PRP.
  • While nail changes can occur in PRP, they are not as characteristic as the islands of sparing.

 

Option B. Pterygium

 

  • This is a finding more commonly associated with lichen planus and involves the progression of skin to encroach upon the nails, which is not a feature of PRP.

 

Option D. Herald patch

 

  • It is associated with Pityriasis Rosea, a different condition that presents with a large, solitary patch followed by a generalized body rash, not typically seen in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Islands of sparing is a distinctive clinical sign in patients with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris, which can aid in differentiating it from other erythrodermic skin diseases.

Option A: Dermatitis is an umbrella term, covering many skin conditions associated with inflammation of skin including Eczema, so All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema.

 

Option B: The hallmark symptom of eczema is intense pruritus.

Her personal history reveals a chronic & recurrent course of these lesions; family history is positive for asthma. Identify the FALSE statement related to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has a Flexural Distribution in Infantile Phase

 

Option C:

 

  • The image showing Scratch Marks & Excoriations due to Pruritic Lesion at a Flexural Site along with a personal history of chronic & recurrent course & a family history of atopy (Asthma) is suggestive of Atopic Dermatitis (AD) or Atopic Eczema (AE) (Option A)
  • Flexural distribution is seen in Childhood & Adult Phase & Extensor distribution in Infantile Phase.
  • It is a Chronic or chronically relapsing Inflammatory Condition.
  • The first site of involvement in infants with atopic eczema is the face.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected

 

 

  • Erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, which frequently begin in early childhood, are how it manifests.
  • Later, the lesions develop excoriation and Lichenification. It frequently has a relationship with secondary infections & skin dryness.
  • The UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of Atopic dermatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema):

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus three or more of the following:
  1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  3. History of a generally dry skin
  4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)
     

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge
     

Dennie morgan fold

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis in infants typically involves the face and extensor surfaces rather than flexural areas, which are more commonly affected in older children and adults.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the ENT outpatient department for a routine dressing. Shortly after the dressing is applied, he develops an erythematous and oozing reaction around his ear, as shown in the accompanying image. The patient denies previous similar reactions. The dressing material contained povidone-iodine, which the patient has been exposed for the first time now. What is TRUE about the patient's reaction to the dressing change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is associated with severe burning rather than Itching

 

Option B:

 

  • The patient's symptoms are consistent with irritant contact dermatitis (ICD), which is a non-allergic reaction to a chemical irritant, in this case, povidone-iodine. ICD is characterized more by a burning sensation rather than itching, which is more typical of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).

 

 

Explanation:

Option C. Memory T cells are involved - Incorrect.

 

  • Memory T cells are involved in allergic reactions, not in the non-immunologic reactions of ICD.

 

Option D. Patch testing can confirm the diagnosis once the acute phase is managed - Incorrect.

 

  • Patch testing is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis, not ICD.
  • However, it may still be used if an allergic component is suspected after the acute phase of ICD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To distinguish between irritant contact dermatitis and allergic contact dermatitis based on symptoms and underlying mechanisms. ICD is characterized by a burning sensation and results from direct toxicity, not an immune-mediated response.

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color of the Human Skin depends upon the Number of Melanocytes.

 

Option A: Color of the human skin depends upon the number of melanocytes

 

The color of the human skin does NOT depend on the number of melanocytes.

 

The following factors determine the skin's color:

 

  1. The concentration of melanin within melanocytes
  2. The quantity and size of melanosomes
  3. The extent to which melanin is transferred into keratinocytes.

 

Melanin, a pigment produced by melanocytes, is what gives skin its color.

 

Melanocytes are dendritic cells that are found in the stratum basale layer of epidermis and are descended from neural crest cells.

 

The cell organelles known as melanosomes are where each melanocyte stores the melanin it produces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: These melanosomes are distributed to the 36 keratinocytes that make up the "epidermal melanin" unit via the dendritic processes of melanocytes. (The ratio of the epidermal melanin unit is 36 keratinocytes: 1 melanocyte)

 

Option B: Melasma in pregnant women is called as Chloasma or mask of pregnancy.

 

Clinical Image depicting Melasma

 

 

  • The third trimester of pregnancy is when chloasma is most prevalent and is most noticeable in brunettes.
  • It results from elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone stimulating melanocyte activity.
  • Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper-functional melanocytes. Once the pregnancy is over, it resolves naturally.
  • The most frequent cause of chronic facial melanosis is melasma. Hyperpigmented macules that are more pronounced after exposure to sunlight are its primary symptom. Upper lip, malar, forehead, and chin are the main areas of the body affected by this hyper melanosis. Women between the ages of 20 and 40 are more likely to have it.
  • It is due to increased levels of estrogen & progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper functional melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy.
  • It is frequently seen in women on OCPs.

 

Woods lamp examination is useful to differentiate various types of Melasma, level of pigmentation & treatment response:

 

 

  • Melasma is more Chronic & requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:
  • Kligman triple combination- Topical Hydroquinone + Tretinoin + Steroid compound cream (First Line)
  • Hydroquinone (reduces Tyrosinase Activity)
  • Kojic Acid (Tyrosinase Inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

 

Option D: Para-Tertiary Butyl Phenol is the culprit behind bindi Leukoderma (PTBP). It is present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

Clinical Image depicting Bindi Leucoderma

 

 

  • This condition is known as chemical or contact leukoderma, in which the chemical increases sensitivity and causes the melanocytes in the area of contact to undergo apoptosis.
  • Additionally, there is proof that azo dyes, which share structural similarities with tyrosine and compete with it for the binding of the tyrosinase enzyme, can directly inhibit melanogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct identification of skin colour being determined by melanin production and NOT by the number of melanocytes is crucial for understanding the pathophysiology of pigmentary disorders.

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

Option C: The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne Contact Dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test.

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This time frame is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours –

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patch testing, the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction.

 

  • 48 hours: Patch removal for initial reading to detect early hypersensitivity reactions
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation and for detecting late reactions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male construction worker presents with itchy, red, and weeping plaques on his palms and forearms, as depicted in the image. He reports that the rash developed shortly after he started working with wet cement on a new project. He denies any known allergies or atopic history. On examination, the skin lesions are erythematous, with vesicles and some crusting, localized to areas of contact with cement. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start with Steroids

 

Option D:

 

  • The presentation is suggestive of Allergic contact dermatitis, commonly seen with cement due to the presence of substances like chromium (Potassium Dichromate).

 

 

 

  • Topical steroids are the mainstay of treatment for acute inflammatory dermatitis to reduce inflammation and itching.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Check IgE levels - Incorrect.

 

  • Elevated IgE levels are associated with atopic dermatitis and allergies, but this does not have any role in management of the given patient.

 

Option B. Perform patch test to confirm the diagnosis - Incorrect.

 

  • While a patch test is useful in identifying specific allergens in allergic contact dermatitis, the immediate management should focus on alleviating the patient's symptoms and preventing further skin damage.
  • Patch test should NOT be performed when active lesions are present.

 

Option C. Start with Antihistamines - Incorrect.

 

  • Antihistamines can be used to alleviate itching but do NOT address the underlying inflammation, which is the primary pathology in contact dermatitis. Therefore, steroids are more appropriate for initial management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The management of contact dermatitis, particularly in occupational settings like construction work where cement exposure is common.
  • Treatment with topical steroids should be initiated to reduce inflammation and provide symptomatic relief.
  • Medical students should be aware that while patch testing is useful for diagnosis, the immediate treatment of the dermatitis should NOT be delayed for testing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with widespread, red, scaly, and flaky skin that covers more than 90% of his body surface area, as depicted in the image. He reports that the rash started on his scalp and has progressively involved his entire body over the past few weeks. He also complains of severe itching and scaling. His medical history is significant for mild dandruff. He denies any recent infections, drug intake, or history of blistering disorders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

Option B: The description given in this case scenario is supportive of the diagnosis of Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis.

 

Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis:

 

  • It is a severe and potentially life-threatening skin disorder characterized by widespread redness and scaling of the skin.

 

Causes of Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis:

 

 

  • In this question, case scenario of a patient with a history of dandruff and widespread erythematous, scaly, and flaky skin, particularly starting on the scalp and progression to cover a significant area of the body is suggestive of SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS.
  • SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS can present with erythroderma, especially in severe cases.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis often starts with flaky, yellow greasy scaly skin on the scalp (dandruff) and can spread to other seborrheic areas like:
  1. Scalp
  2. Forehead
  3. Eyebrows
  4. Eyelids (along the Lash Line)
  5. Nasolabial Folds (the lines from the Nose to the Corners of the Mouth)
  6. External Ear Canals
  7. Postauricular (behind the Ears) Areas
  8. Sternum (Middle of the Chest)

 

 

Seborrheic dermatitis presenting with yellow greasy scaly skin over face in a child is depicted in the above image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a blistering autoimmune disorder characterized by intraepidermal blisters and erosions but is not typically associated with the widespread erythematous and scaling rash seen in the patient.

 

Option C. Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

 

  • SJS is an acute and severe mucocutaneous reaction, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epidermal detachment resembling burns, mucosal involvement, and systemic symptoms, which is not consistent with the gradual progression and symptoms described.

 

Option D. Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis

 

  • TEN is a more severe form of SJS with extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membranes, high mortality, and is typically drug-induced.
  • The clinical picture described does not include the acute, severe blistering or systemic symptoms typical of TEN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose seborrheic dermatitis when presented with a patient with a history of dandruff and widespread erythematous, scaly, and flaky skin, particularly when it starts on the scalp and progresses to cover a significant area of the body.

questions.text: In which of the following are Max Joseph Spaces characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen Planus

 

Option A.

 

  • Max Joseph spaces refer to areas of degeneration within the epidermis, specifically in the basal layer, which is a feature seen in lichen planus.

 

Lichen Planus

 

  • Lichen planus is characterised by the degeneration or destruction of basal epidermal cells. This degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max Joseph spaces.
  • It happens as a result of dermal CD8 + T lymphocytes destroying basal keratinocytes.
  • Colloid bodies, also known as cytoid or Civatte bodies, are degenerating basal epidermal cells that can appear singly or in clusters.

 

Other histopathological characteristics of lichen planus include:

 

  • Hyperkeratosis, Hypergranulosis,
  • Pigment incontinence (melanin slowly migrates into the dermis as a result of keratinocyte degeneration), engulfment of dermal melanin by macrophages to form Melanophages (melanin-containing macrophages) and
  • The development of Max Joseph spaces in the epidermis.
  • There is a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction; the rete ridges have a saw-toothed appearance because they are pointed at their lower ends.

 

The image below shows the HPE of Lichen planus with arrows pointing out Saw toothed appearance of Rete ridges:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • It is characterized by Munro micro abscesses and regular acanthosis, not typically associated with Max Joseph spaces.

 

Option C. Pemphigus

 

  • This involves intra-epidermal blisters and acantholysis, especially seen in Pemphigus vulgaris, not Max Joseph spaces.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

  • It shows follicular plugging and psoriasiform hyperplasia.
  • Max Joseph spaces are not a feature of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Max Joseph spaces a is a histological feature of Lichen Planus, which is important for the microscopic diagnosis of this condition.

questions.text: ___________________ Demarcates Hair into Upper & Lower Hair Follicles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arrector Pili Muscle

 

Option C. Arrector Pili Muscle:

 

  • It is a small band of smooth muscle that connects the hair follicle to the dermal tissue.
     
  • It plays a role in the thermoregulation mechanism by causing hair to stand erect ('goose bumps') when contracted, which can provide insulation.
     
  • This muscle's attachment point to the hair follicle demarcates the boundary between the upper and lower follicle, with the upper portion being associated with the sebaceous gland and the pilo sebaceous unit above the muscle attachment, and the lower portion being below this point, encompassing the hair bulb and the region where active hair growth occurs.
     
  • Upper and lower hair follicles are separated by the arrector pili. The portion above arrector pili constitutes the upper hair follicle while the portion below constitutes the lower hair follicle.
  • Attachement of Sebaceous Gland divides Upper Segement into Upper Infundibulum & Lower Isthmus. Apocrine Gland attaches above Sebaceous Gland. Lower Segment is divided into Upper Stem & Lower Bulb by Adamson`s Fringe.

 

 

Structure of hair follicle

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stem Cells:

  • They are primarily located in the bulge region of the hair follicle, play a crucial role in the regeneration and growth cycle of the hair but do not serve as a demarcating boundary between the upper and lower segments of the hair follicle.

 

Option B. Huxley’s Layer:

  • It is part of the inner root sheath and is involved in the structural support and shaping of the growing hair shaft. It does not demarcate the hair follicle into upper and lower segments.

 

Huxley’s & Henley’s layers are part of Inner Root Sheath (IRS)

 

As can be seen in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D. Adamson’s fringe:

  • This refers to the point where the inner root sheath disintegrates and the hair shaft emerges, marking the transition from the non-keratinized to the keratinized part of the hair shaft within the follicle.
  • It is not considered a demarcation point between the upper and lower hair follicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arrector pili muscle's insertion point demarcates the boundary between the upper and lower segments of the hairfollicle.

Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features {ATP}
 

  • Atrophy of skin
  • Telangiectasia (Permanently Dilated Blood Vessels)
  • Pigment Abnormalities (Dyspigmentation, both Hypo & Hyper)

 

 

Poikiloderma may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with Mycosis Fungoides, Dermatomyositis, Xeroderma Pigmentosum etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Poikiloderma is characterized by a triad of changes: pigment abnormalities, telangiectasia, and atrophy of the skin.
  • The Auspitz sign is not part of this triad but is associated with psoriasis

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.12

questions.text: Which of the following disease has a dermatomal distribution of cutaneous lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

Option A: Herpes Zoster - Also known as shingles, this disease is caused by the reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), which remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia after a primary chickenpox infection. Upon reactivation, the virus causes a painful rash that is typically limited to one dermatome, a specific area of the skin innervated by a single nerve.

Herpes zoster has a Dermatomal /Zosteriform distribution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Herpes Genitalis - This condition is caused by the herpes simplex virus (usually type 2, and sometimes type 1). The lesions are vesicular and ulcerative but are not distributed along dermatomes; they are localized to the genital and surrounding areas.

 

In Herpes labialis & genitalis, which are produced by Herpes simplex viruses, grouped vesicles can be seen near lips & genitalia respectively.

 

Option C. Incontinentiapigmenti - This is a genetic disorder affecting the skin, hair, teeth, and nails, often with swirled patterns of discoloration on the skin. It does not follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis - This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrixschenckii, typically contracted from soil or plant matter. The cutaneous form of sporotrichosis is characterized by nodular lesions along the lymphatic channels, not by dermatomal distribution.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes zoster is the condition among the options provided that is associated with a dermatomal distribution of cutaneous lesions, following the pathway of a single spinal or cranial sensory nerve.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology in General Medicine 8th Edition, Pages 39-41

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common manifestation of Nail Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pitting

 

Option C: Nail pitting is the most common manifestation of nail psoriasis. It appears as small, pinpoint depressions on the nail surface.

 

 

  • The pitting is due to the psoriatic disruption of keratinocyte adhesion in the nail matrix.
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Onycholysis:

 

  • Onycholysis is the separation of the nail from the nail bed and is seen in nail psoriasis, but it is not the most frequent feature.
  • It typically occurs in more severe cases and can be quite distressing to patients due to the functional impairment it can cause.


Option B. Yellow Discoloration:

 

  • Yellow discoloration is less common than pitting.
  • It represents a build-up of psoriatic material in the nail bed.


Option D. Subungual Hyperkeratosis:

 

  • Subungual hyperkeratosis is the accumulation of scales beneath the distal nail plate, which can lead to nail plate elevation and is seen in nail psoriasis, but pitting is more commonly the initial finding.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Nail pitting is the most common clinical manifestation of nail psoriasis, characterized by small, pinpoint depressions on the nail plate.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 8thEdition Page No 1014

questions.text: What is the level of pathology in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nail Bed

 

Option B: Lindsay's nails, or half-and-half nails, have a distinct appearance with the proximal portion being white and the distal portion a normal pink or brown, which is due to pathology in the nail bed causing these color changes.

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nail Plate:

  • Image depicts Lindsay nails / Half and Half nails which is an example for apparent leukonychia and is seen associated with Chronic renal failure and the pathology is in the nail bed not Nail plate.
     

Option C. Distal Nail Matrix:

  • Incorrect as pathology in the distal nail matrix would affect the formation of the nail plate itself, leading to changes in the texture or thickness of the nail plate as it grows out.
     

Option D. Proximal Nail Matrix:

  • Incorrect because changes in the proximal nail matrix would typically affect the mostsuperficial part of the nail plate as it forms, not the nail bed.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • The pathology in Lindsay's nails, known as half-and-half nails, is located in the nail bed, which manifests as a bicolored appearance of the nails.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.14
